questions.text: Match the following poison and site of action : (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A-1,B-2,C-3,D-4

 

The correct matches for the poisons and their primary sites of action, based on typical pharmacological effects, are:

 

Option A. Datura: Acts on the CNS (Central Nervous System) due to its content of tropane alkaloids which cause anticholinergic effects.

 

Option B. Nicotine: Primarily affects the cardiovascular system (CVS), influencing heart rate and blood pressure through its stimulant effects on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

 

Option C. Nitric Acid: Its primary contact effect is on the skin, causing severe burns upon exposure.

 

Option D. Nux Vomica: Contains strychnine, which affects the spinal cord (spine), leading to heightened reflex excitability and convulsions.

 

Educational objective :

 

  • A-1: Datura acts on the CNS.
  • B-2: Nicotine affects the CVS.
  • C-3: Nitric Acid affects the Skin.
  • D-4: Nux Vomica acts on the Spine.

choices.text: Compression of the inferior vena cava
Compression of the superior vena cava

questions.text: A pregnant woman has dizziness on lying down straight and this improves when she turns to one side. A possible explanation is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Compression of the inferior vena cava

 

Explanation:

 

The scenario described is characteristic of supine hypotensive syndrome, which occurs when a pregnant woman lies flat on her back, causing the gravid uterus to compress the inferior vena cava (IVC). This compression decreases venous return to the heart, leading to reduced cardiac output and subsequent hypotension and dizziness.

 

Symptoms of dizziness and hypotension improve when the woman turns to her side (Left tilt), relieving the compression on the IVC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Compression of the aorta: While the aorta can also be compressed, the primary issue in supine hypotensive syndrome is the reduced venous return due to IVC compression.

 

Option C. Compression of the superior vena cava: This is less likely to be affected by the position of the uterus during pregnancy.
 

Option D. Compression of the pulmonary vessels: This is not typically related to positional changes during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine hypotensive syndrome is caused by the compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus when a pregnant woman lies flat on her back. This condition is relieved by turning to one side, which reduces the compression and improves venous return to the heart.

questions.text: A child presents with breathlessness. On chest X-ray, the following object is seen. Identify? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Button battery

 

Explanation:

 

The image youâ€™ve provided shows a radiopaque object in the esophagus of a child, which is identified as a button battery.

 

On X-rays, button batteries typically present as small, circular objects with a double rim or halo effect. This is because they have a distinctive two-layer structure which shows up clearly on radiographs. The appearance in the X-ray  is characteristic of a button battery, with a clearly visible double rim. This is a medical emergency due to the risk of rapid and severe damage to the mucosal tissues from electrical discharge and leakage of caustic substances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coin: Coins are also circular and radiopaque on X-rays but lack the double rim feature seen with button batteries. Coins tend to be uniform in density throughout. Although they are a common type of foreign body ingested by children, they generally pose less immediate danger compared to button batteries.

 

Option C. Ball: A small ball, depending on its material, might appear on an X-ray if it's dense enough. However, it would not typically show the structured double rim characteristic of a button battery.

 

Option D. Bottle Cap: Bottle caps may appear circular but would show irregular edges or threading and do not have the double rim appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate identification and removal of an ingested button battery are crucial due to the rapid damage that can occur. Emergency endoscopic retrieval is usually necessary to prevent severe injury or death.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior rib

 

The marked structure in the provided chest X-ray image points to the horizontal part of the rib, which is indicative of the posterior rib. In radiographic anatomy, the posterior ribs are visualized as horizontal structures on a chest X-ray, whereas the anterior ribs appear more curved as they wrap around the thoracic cavity. This distinction is crucial for identifying the ribs accurately.

 

The posterior ribs are highlighted because they are flatter and more horizontal compared to the anterior ribs, which curve forward.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior rib: The anterior ribs are more curved and not horizontal like the posterior ribs. The marked structure clearly shows a horizontal rib, which excludes the anterior rib as the correct answer.

 

Option C. Costal cartilage: Costal cartilage does not show up on standard X-rays because it is not as radiopaque as bone. Therefore, it cannot be the marked structure.

 

Option D. Pulmonary artery: The pulmonary artery would appear in the lung hilum and would not resemble the horizontal rib structure. Thus, it is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior rib appears as a horizontal structure on a chest X-ray, distinguishing it from the more curved anterior ribs and other thoracic structures.

questions.text: Angular stomatitis and glossitis are associated with which vitamin deficiency?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Riboflavin

 

Explanation: 

 

Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency is most characteristically associated with angular stomatitis, also known as cheilosis, which is inflammation of the corners of the mouth. Additionally, riboflavin deficiency can lead to atrophic glossitis, also referred to as geographic tongue. These oral manifestations are the hallmark signs of riboflavin deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency results in pellagra, which is characterized by the "4 D's": diarrhea, dermatitis (especially around the Casal's necklace), dementia, and death if left untreated. While pellagra can have significant consequences, it is not primarily associated with angular stomatitis and glossitis.

 

Option C. Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency can cause beriberi in populations consuming polished rice and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome in chronic alcoholics. Beriberi affects the nervous and cardiovascular systems, while Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by neurological symptoms. However, thiamine deficiency is not directly linked to angular stomatitis and glossitis.

 

Option D. Cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency is common in strict vegetarians and can lead to peripheral neuropathy, megaloblastic anemia, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord as a severe complication. Pernicious anemia may also occur as a result of vitamin B12 deficiency. While these conditions are serious, they are not specifically associated with angular stomatitis and glossitis.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Angular stomatitis (cheilosis) and atrophic glossitis (geographic tongue) are the most characteristic oral manifestations of riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency.

questions.text: A bank employee, felt depressed with no interest in activities, came to AIIMS OPD. He was started on escitalopram. Which of these adverse effects cannot be explained with escitalopram? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sialorrhea

 

Sialorrhea, or excessive saliva production, is not a common side effect of SSRIs like escitalopram. It is more commonly associated with the atypical antipsychotic drug clozapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia, or difficulty achieving orgasm, is a well-known side effect of SSRIs due to their impact on serotonin levels, which can interfere with sexual function.

 

Option C. Nausea: Nausea is one of the most common side effects of SSRIs. It typically occurs at the beginning of treatment and may subside with continued use.

 

Option D. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams are another common side effect of SSRIs. They occur due to the influence of increased serotonin levels on sleep patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Escitalopram is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI).
  • Other SSRIs include Fluoxetine, Paroxetine, Fluvoxamine etc.
  • Side-effects of SSRI include:
  • Most common: Nausea, Vomiting
  • Next most common: Anxiety etc.
  • Other side effects- Delayed ejaculation, anorgasmia, diarrhea, vivid dreams etc.
  • Main drug which causes sialorrhea is CLOZAPINE (an atypical anti-psychotic drug)

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/488

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 35-year-old patient who has presented with easily rupturing flaccid bulla on the skin and whose biopsy indicates a suprabasal split?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • Based on the clinical presentation of bullous lesions and the histologic finding of a suprabasal blister, Pemphigus vulgaris is suspected.
  • This condition involves the production of antibodies, particularly against Desmoglein 3, and sometimes Desmoglein 1. These antibodies are typically of the IgG type. Desmoglein 3 is primarily found in the basal and suprabasal layers of the skin and mucosa.
  • As a result, patients exhibit flaccid bullae on the skin, and mucosal involvement, especially in the oral mucosa, is common.

 

 

  • Ulceration may also occur in other areas such as the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, and larynx. Cutaneous lesions are more frequently observed on the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus Vegetans:

  • Description: Pemphigus vegetans is a variant of pemphigus vulgaris. It features vesicles and bullae that evolve into verrucous (wart-like) lesions, particularly in skin folds.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The primary presentation in the question doesn't describe verrucous or wart-like lesions.

 

Option C. Pemphigus foliaceus:

  • Description: Pemphigus foliaceus is another type of pemphigus but is characterized by more superficial skin blisters than pemphigus vulgaris, and it doesn't typically involve the mucous membranes.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The biopsy of pemphigus foliaceus would show a split in the upper epidermis (subcorneal), not a suprabasal split.

 

Option D. Erythema multiforme:

  • Description: Erythema multiforme is an acute, immune-mediated skin condition. It is characterized by target-like lesions and is often triggered by infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus) or certain medications.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The presentation of erythema multiforme is quite distinct with its target-like lesions, and a biopsy would not reveal a suprabasal split.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is identified by the presence of flaccid bullae that rupture easily and a suprabasal split on biopsy, indicating an autoimmune process causing loss of epidermal cell adhesion.

 

 

Reference: 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 47.1-47.5, 50.1-50.10

Online resources:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3884912/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17619399/

choices.text: Needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space
CT scan of the chest

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident presented with subcutaneous emphysema, respiratory distress, and hypotension. On auscultation, there was no air entry on the right side and a hyper-resonant note was felt on percussion. X-ray is shown. What will be your immediate management? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space

 

The clinical presentation of subcutaneous emphysema, respiratory distress, hypotension, absent air entry, and hyper-resonant note on percussion strongly suggests a tension pneumothorax. This condition is confirmed by the X-ray, which shows a dark lung field on the right side due to air in the pleural space, a collapsed lung border, and a shift of the mediastinum and trachea to the left side.

 

Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention to relieve the pressure in the pleural space. The recommended immediate management is needle thoracostomy, which involves the insertion of a wide-bore needle into the 5th intercostal space in the mid-axillary line to rapidly decompress the pleural space, followed by the insertion of a chest drain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgent tracheostomy: This is not the immediate management for tension pneumothorax. Tracheostomy is typically performed to secure the airway in cases of upper airway obstruction.

 

Option C. IV fluids: While IV fluids may be administered to manage hypotension, they do not address the underlying cause of tension pneumothorax and are not the immediate life-saving intervention required.

 

Option D. CT scan of the chest: Imaging studies like a CT scan are not performed immediately in cases of tension pneumothorax due to the urgent need for decompression to prevent cardiovascular collapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate management for tension pneumothorax is needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space in the mid-axillary line, followed by the insertion of a chest drain.

questions.text: Exclusive breastfeeding is done for? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 months

 

Explanation:

 

Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first 6 months of a baby's life. During this period, the infant receives only breast milk without any additional food or drink, not even water. Breast milk provides all the essential nutrients, antibodies, and hydration needed for optimal growth and development during these first crucial months. The World Health Organization (WHO) and other health authorities strongly advocate for exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months due to its significant health benefits for both the baby and the mother.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exclusive breastfeeding should be practiced for the first 6 months of a baby's life to ensure they receive optimal nutrition and immune support.

choices.text: 2 doctors
1 doctor
Medical board
Cannot be done

questions.text: According to MTP Act, MTP at 22 weeks of gestation due to contraceptive failure requires opinion from:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cannot be done

 

Explanation:

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act in India, MTP at 22 weeks of gestation due to contraceptive failure cannot be legally performed. The MTP Act allows termination of pregnancy due to contraceptive failure only up to 20 weeks of gestation.

 

For pregnancies between 20 and 24 weeks, MTP is permitted only in certain aggravated conditions, such as:

 

  • Rape
  • Minors
  • Disabled women
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Widowhood

 

Contraceptive failure is not included in the list of aggravated conditions for which MTP is allowed between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation.

 

Other options:

 

Option. A. 2 doctors: This would be the requirement for MTP between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation in the case of aggravated conditions, but not for contraceptive failure.

 

Option. B. 1 doctor: This is the requirement for MTP up to 20 weeks of gestation, but not for the given scenario of 22 weeks due to contraceptive failure.

 

Option. C. Medical board: A medical board's opinion is required for MTP beyond 24 weeks of gestation, and only in cases of congenital anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

  •  Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.
  •  Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.
  • Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.
  •  Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: According to triage, which of the following colors indicates the highest priority?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

Explanation:

 

In the triage system, the red color indicates the highest priority. The triage categories and their corresponding colors are as follows:

 

Red: Category 1, highest priority. Patients requiring immediate resuscitation or life-saving surgery within 0 to 6 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow: Category 2, high priority. Possible resuscitation or possible surgery within 6 to 24 hours.

 

Option C. Green: Category 3, low priority. Ambulatory patients with non-life-threatening injuries.

 

Option D. Black: Least priority, includes dead and moribund patients.

 

The red category, which is assigned to patients requiring immediate life-saving intervention, is the highest priority in the triage system.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest sign in Crohn's disease? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aphthous ulcers

 

These are shallow, round ulcers that are often seen in the mouth but can also occur in the small intestine and colon in Crohn's disease. They are the earliest sign of Crohn's disease and are often recurrent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobblestone appearance: This is a characteristic finding in Crohn's disease and refers to the appearance of the mucosa with raised, rounded, and separated areas resembling cobblestones. This is caused by transmural inflammation and can be seen in the terminal ileum and colon.

 

Option B. Deep fissured ulcers: These are another feature of Crohn's disease that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract. They are deep, often extend into the submucosa, and can lead to the formation of fistulas or abscesses.

 

Option C. Rose-thorn appearance: This term is sometimes used to describe the appearance of the mucosa in Crohn's disease, where there are linear ulcers that are surrounded by raised, edematous tissue. This pattern is more commonly seen in the colon.

 

Educational Objective:


Aphthous ulcers are the earliest sign of Crohn's disease, often appearing in the mouth and gastrointestinal tract before more severe lesions develop.

choices.text: ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿Velamentous insertion of the cord
ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿Both succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion

questions.text: The given image depicts: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion

 

Explanation:

 

  • Succenturiate lobe: This refers to a placenta with one or more accessory lobes connected to the main part of the placenta by blood vessels. It is characterized by the presence of a smaller, separate lobe in addition to the main placental mass.
  • Velamentous insertion of the cord: This occurs when the umbilical cord inserts into the fetal membranes (chorioamnion) rather than directly into the placental mass. The vessels then travel through the membranes to reach the placenta, making them vulnerable to rupture.
  • The image shows both conditions: a smaller accessory lobe (succenturiate lobe) and the cord inserting into the membranes rather than the placenta (velamentous insertion).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Succenturiate lobe: This option is partially correct but does not account for the velamentous insertion.

 

Option B. Velamentous insertion of the cord: This option is partially correct but does not account for the succenturiate lobe.

 

Option D. Normal placenta: This is incorrect as the image shows abnormalities not seen in a normal placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A placenta with both a succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion of the cord is characterized by the presence of a smaller accessory lobe and the umbilical cord inserting into the fetal membranes.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg122, 117, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 251,253

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came with complaints of sudden onset ocular pain and haemorrhagic discharge accompanied with diminution of vision. He is suspected to have acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis. What is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Enterovirus 70

 

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by enterovirus 70, a picornavirus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterovirus 68: Known to cause respiratory illnesses and has been associated with acute flaccid myelitis, but not typically with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option B. Enterovirus 69: Less commonly associated with conjunctivitis and more related to respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Enterovirus 71: Known to cause hand, foot, and mouth disease and severe neurological diseases, but not typically associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterovirus 70 is the primary causative organism of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, characterized by sudden onset of ocular pain, redness, and hemorrhagic discharge. The condition is highly contagious and typically self-limiting, with supportive care being the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A female had unprotected sexual intercourse and now more than 5 days have passed. She fears getting pregnant. What is the contraceptive of choice in this case? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IUCD

 

The only option suitable for emergency contraception in this scenario (more than 5 days after unprotected intercourse) is the IUCD, specifically the copper IUCD. It can be inserted up to five days after unprotected intercourse and is highly effective in preventing pregnancy. The other options, OCP and Levonorgestrel, are typically used within a shorter time frame after unprotected sex and would not be the best choices in this situation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. OCP (Oral Contraceptive Pills): These are typically used as a regular method of contraception and are not suitable for emergency contraception if more than 72 hours have passed since unprotected intercourse.

 

Option C. Levonorgestrel: This is a form of emergency contraceptive pill. It is most effective when taken within 72 hours (3 days) after unprotected sex and its effectiveness decreases significantly after this period.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option would be chosen if none of the other options were appropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device) is an effective form of emergency contraception. Certain types of IUCDs, particularly the copper IUCD, can be used as emergency contraception if inserted within five days (120 hours) after unprotected intercourse. They are one of the most effective forms of emergency contraception available.

choices.text: MTP can be done routinely after 24 weeks POG
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case only if it threatens the life of the mother
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case with 1 Doctorâ€™s opinion only

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to your hospital emergency with pregnancy 22 weeks, which was a result of rape. Correct statement regarding Medical Termination of Pregnancy is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act of India, MTP is permitted up to 24 weeks of pregnancy. For gestation periods from 0 to 20 weeks, it is considered low risk and only one doctorâ€™s opinion is required.

 

However, for gestation periods from 20 to 24 weeks, it is categorized as high risk, and the approval of two doctors is required. This high-risk category includes specific situations such as rape, incest, disability, and when the woman is a minor. Since the woman in the question is 22 weeks pregnant due to rape, MTP is permissible under these regulations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP can be done routinely after 24 weeks POG: This is incorrect because MTP after 24 weeks is not routinely allowed. It requires a medical board's approval and is only permitted in exceptional cases involving severe fetal anomalies or conditions that endanger the motherâ€™s life.

 

Option C. MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case only if it threatens the life of the mother: This statement is incorrect. For 20-24 weeks POG, MTP is permitted not only for life-threatening conditions but also for cases involving rape, incest, disability, and minors.

 

Option D. MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case with 1 Doctorâ€™s opinion only: This is incorrect because two doctors' opinions are required for high-risk cases between 20-24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP between 20-24 weeks of pregnancy is considered high risk and requires two doctors' opinions, especially in cases of rape, incest, disability, or if the woman is a minor.

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked in the following local anesthesia technique shown in the image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasociliary nerve

 

  • Anatomy: The nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).
  • Procedure: The needle is inserted 1 cm superior and 1.5 cm posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye. A maximum of 2 mL of local anesthetic solution is then slowly injected.
  • Use: This nerve block is used in procedures such as septoplasty, rhinoplasty, and the treatment of nasal bone fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior ethmoidal nerve: The anterior ethmoidal nerve is another branch of the ophthalmic nerve. It innervates the anterior and middle ethmoidal air cells and part of the nasal cavity, but it is not targeted by the described technique.

 

Option C. Sphenopalatine nerve: The sphenopalatine nerve, also known as the nasopalatine nerve, is a branch of the maxillary nerve (another branch of the trigeminal nerve). It supplies the nasal septum and the anterior part of the hard palate, but the described technique does not target this nerve.

 

Option D. Greater palatine nerve: The greater palatine nerve is also a branch of the maxillary nerve. It innervates the hard palate and the palatal gingiva, and is not targeted by the described technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The nasociliary nerve block involves inserting a needle superior and posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye and injecting a local anesthetic solution. This technique is primarily used for procedures involving the nasal area, such as septoplasty, rhinoplasty, and nasal bone fracture treatment.

 

Ref: Millerâ€™s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2413-2414

choices.text: Temperature >38 degree Celsius or <36 degree Celsius

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with symptoms of fever, increased respiratory rate, elevated heart rate, and low blood pressure. The physician suspects the patient may have SIRS. Which of the following is not a criteria for SIRS? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg.

 

SIRS is diagnosed when two or more of the following criteria are present: hyperthermia or hypothermia, Tachypnea or low PaCO2, Tachycardia, and abnormal white blood cell count. Systolic blood pressure is not included in the SIRS criteria. Sepsis is defined as SIRS with a documented infection.

 

This is not a criterion for SIRS. SIRS criteria typically include fever or hypothermia, tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute), tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute), and abnormal white blood cell count. Low blood pressure is more related to septic shock, which can be a consequence of severe sepsis but is not one of the primary criteria for SIRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temperature >38 degrees Celsius or <36 degrees Celsius: This is a criterion for SIRS.

 

Option C. Respiratory rate >20 bpm: This is a criterion for SIRS. Elevated respiratory rate (>20 breaths per minute) or paCO2 < 32 mm of Hg is one of the criteria used to diagnose SIRS.

 

Option D. Heart rate >90 min: This is a criterion for SIRS. Tachycardia, defined as a heart rate greater than 90 beats per minute, is one of the key criteria for SIRS.

 

In summary, Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg (option A) is not a criterion for SIRS, while the other options (B, C, and D) are all criteria for SIRS.

questions.text: Match the surgery with related nerve injuries: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

 

The following are the associations between the type of surgery and the nerve most commonly at risk of injury:

 

A. Breast surgery - Long Thoracic Nerve: The Long Thoracic Nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which anchors the scapula to the chest wall. Injury to this nerve during breast surgery, especially radical mastectomies where axillary lymph nodes are removed, can lead to a condition called "winged scapula," where the medial border of the scapula protrudes outwards.

 

B. Thyroid surgery - External Laryngeal nerve: The External Laryngeal nerve is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (itself a branch of the vagus nerve). It supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which plays a role in tensioning the vocal cords. Injury during thyroid surgery can lead to voice changes, particularly affecting the pitch.

 

C. Submandibular excision - Hypoglossal nerve: The Hypoglossal nerve is the twelfth cranial nerve and supplies the muscles of the tongue. Injury to this nerve during excision of the submandibular gland can lead to tongue deviation towards the side of the injury due to the unopposed action of the tongue muscles on the unaffected side.

 

D. Thymectomy - Vagus nerve: The Vagus nerve, or the tenth cranial nerve, has a wide range of functions including supplying parasympathetic fibers to many organs in the thorax and abdomen. Injury during thymectomy, a surgical procedure to can have multiple effects, including voice changes due to its role in innervating the larynx. However, it's worth noting that the phrenic nerve, which innervates the diaphragm, is also at risk during a thymectomy.

 

In summary, during surgical procedures, it's imperative to be aware of the nearby nerves and their courses to prevent unintended nerve injury, as this can lead to significant postoperative complications

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a fever. He is an intravenous drug user. On examination, a temperature of 38.5Â°C, and some spots can be noted over the fundus. CBC showed a leukocyte count of 20,000/cu mm. Blood has been sent for culture. Infective Endocarditis is suspected. How many minor Duke's Criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

Explanation:

 

Duke's Criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis include both major and minor criteria. In this case, the minor criteria that are satisfied include:

 

  1. Fever > 38Â°C: The patient has a fever of 38.5Â°C.
  2. Predisposing heart condition or intravenous drug use: The patient is an intravenous drug user.
  3. Immunologic phenomena: The presence of spots over the fundus suggests Roth spots, which are a form of immunologic phenomenon.

 

The other minor criteria â€“

 

  1. Vascular phenomena
  2. Blood culture is positive, but not meeting major criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Only fever would be counted.

 

Option B. 2: Fever and IV drug use would be counted.

 

Option D. 4: This would require additional minor criteria that are not mentioned in the question.

 

Additional Information -

 

Dukeâ€™s Major criteria for IE â€“

 

  • Blood culture persistently positive for typical microorganism ( â‰¥3 blood culture) from different puncture sides and gap between first and last culture should be atleast 1 hour: for diagnosis 2 out of 3 culture should be positive and for the same organism. Except Q fever -Coxiella Brunetti only single culture is enough.
  •  Imaging â€“ Positive Echocardiogram â€“ For IE specifically Transesophageal Echo â€“ will show vegetation near the valves

 

Educational Objective:

 

In this case, three minor Duke's criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis: fever > 38Â°C, intravenous drug use, and immunologic phenomena (Roth spots).

questions.text:
Countercurrent mechanism is present in which of the following parts of the body?(INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Eye

2. Testes

3. Kidney

4. Gut

5. Lungs
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1,2,3,4,5 are correct

 

The countercurrent mechanism is present in various parts of the body where the inflow and outflow run parallel and in opposite directions, facilitating efficient exchange processes:

 

  1. Eye: The theory of counter-current mechanisms predicts that there is diffusion of oxygen from retinal arterioles into adjacent retinal venules. A possible counter-current exchange was investigated by measuring hemoglobin oxygen saturation (SatO2) in first-order retinal arterioles and venules at different distances from the optic disc.
  2. Testes: The temperature is regulated to be low for spermatogenesis by heat exchange between spermatic arteries and veins in a countercurrent manner.
  3. Kidney: The urine is concentrated using countercurrent exchangers, particularly in the loop of Henle and the vasa recta.
  4. Gut: Certain parts of the gut use countercurrent mechanisms to optimize nutrient absorption.
  5. Lungs: Countercurrent mechanisms in the lungs help in efficient gas exchange.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The countercurrent mechanism is a biological system found in various organs such as the eye, testes, kidney, gut, and lungs, allowing for efficient exchange and regulation processes.

questions.text: Giving TPN (total para-enteral nutrition) in a patient in ICU with metabolic syndrome predisposes to: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperglycemia


Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) in a patient with metabolic syndrome predisposes to hyperglycemia. Metabolic syndrome is characterized by insulin resistance, often seen in conditions such as type 2 diabetes, obesity, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and, in some cases, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Insulin resistance impairs the bodyâ€™s ability to utilize glucose efficiently. When TPN, which is high in glucose, is administered, the already compromised insulin response leads to elevated blood glucose levels, resulting in hyperglycemia. This is a common complication in patients receiving TPN, especially those with underlying metabolic conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reactive Hypoglycemia: Reactive hypoglycemia is a condition where blood glucose levels drop excessively after eating, due to an overproduction of insulin. It is not typically associated with TPN or metabolic syndrome, as TPN administration generally leads to hyperglycemia rather than hypoglycemia due to insulin resistance.

 

Option C. Hyperlipidemia: While hyperlipidemia is a component of metabolic syndrome, it is not a direct complication specifically associated with TPN. Although TPN can contain lipids, its primary complication related to metabolic syndrome is hyperglycemia due to glucose intolerance.

 

Option D. Hyperuricemia: Hyperuricemia, characterized by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood, can be associated with metabolic syndrome but is not directly induced by TPN administration. The primary metabolic disturbance from TPN in these patients is related to glucose management rather than uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In patients with metabolic syndrome, TPN can exacerbate hyperglycemia due to pre-existing insulin resistance. This underscores the need for careful monitoring of blood glucose levels and management of insulin requirements in these patients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents to the clinic with a history of hyperglycemia and has had positive urine glucose tests on two separate occasions in the last six months. The patient has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The physician is considering various medications to manage the patient's condition and prevent potential complications, including renal involvement. Which of the following drugs will not delay renal involvement? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

  • Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used to treat hypertension. 
  • While effective at lowering blood pressure, it does not have specific renal protective effects and may not delay the progression of renal disease in diabetic patients. 
  • In fact, in some cases, thiazide diuretics can increase the risk of developing hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SGLT2 inhibitors: SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., canagliflozin, dapagliflozin) are a class of medications used to lower blood sugar in patients with type 2 diabetes. They work by promoting glucose excretion through the urine. Importantly, SGLT2 inhibitors have been shown to provide renal protection and delay the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

 

Option B. Finerenone: It is a non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist that reduces inflammation and fibrosis in the kidneys. Clinical trials have demonstrated that finerenone can reduce the risk of kidney disease progression in patients with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.

 

Option D. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs): ARBs (e.g., losartan, valsartan) are another class of medications used to manage hypertension and heart failure. Like ACE inhibitors, ARBs have been shown to provide renal protection and delay the progression of diabetic nephropathy by reducing proteinuria and lowering intraglomerular pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, while SGLT2 inhibitors, ACE inhibitors, and ARBs have renal protective properties and can help delay renal involvement in diabetic patients, hydrochlorothiazide does not have these specific protective effects and is the correct answer in this context.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Half fall in 10 min

 

Half fall in 10 min: This is correct. The Miami Criteria for successful parathyroidectomy require a drop in PTH level of more than 50% from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the removal of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

 

The Miami Criteria, also known as the Miami Intraoperative Criteria, refers to a set of guidelines used to confirm successful removal of hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue during parathyroidectomy. The criteria are based on intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

According to the Miami Criteria, a successful parathyroidectomy is indicated if there is a drop in PTH level of more than 50% (half) from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the adenoma. This significant decrease indicates that the source of excess PTH production has been successfully removed.

 

The utility of this approach is that it allows for immediate feedback during surgery about whether all hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue has been removed, reducing the chances of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism post-operatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quarter fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. The Miami Criteria specify a 50% (half) fall, not a 25% (quarter) fall, and the timeframe is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Option B. Quarter fall in 10 min: This is incorrect. While the 10-minute timeframe is correct, the required decrease is 50% (half), not 25% (quarter).

 

Option C. Half fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. Although the 50% (half) fall is correct, the timeframe specified by the Miami Criteria is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Miami Criteria for intraoperative PTH measurement indicate a successful parathyroidectomy if there is a 50% or greater drop in PTH level from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland.

choices.text: Crude birth rate â€“ Crude death rate
Crude birth rate + Crude death rate
Crude birth rate / Crude death rate
Crude birth rate Ã— Crude death rate

questions.text: What is Demographic gap? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Crude birth rate â€“ Crude death rate

 

The demographic gap refers to the difference between the crude birth rate and the crude death rate. It essentially measures the net increase in the population, referred to as the growth rate.

 

In demographic terms:

 

  • A positive demographic gap indicates that the birth rate is higher than the death rate, leading to population growth.
  • A negative demographic gap indicates a declining population when the death rate exceeds the birth rate.

 

The demographic gap is minimal during the early and late stages of the demographic transition model (Stages 1 and 4), where birth and death rates are balanced or declining. It peaks during Stage 2 when the birth rate remains high but the death rate drops significantly. In Stage 3, the gap starts to contract as birth rates begin to fall, and in Stage 5, it can become negative as populations age and birth rates fall below death rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The demographic gap is defined as the difference between the crude birth rate and the crude death rate, representing the population growth rate

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a patient who has paronychia on their index finger and is also showing a reddish streak on their forearm, as depicted in the image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amoxiclav

 

  • The above image depicts paronychia associated with a reddish erythematous streak-like lesion on the hand suggestive of paronychia associated with lymphangitis, which is managed by elevating the affected extremity and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • A broad-spectrum antibiotic like Amoxiclav is appropriate for covering both the pathogens commonly responsible for the initial localized infection and the secondary systemic spread.

 

Acute paronychia:

 

It is infection of the nail fold which is characterized by inflammation, swelling and abscess formation.

Most common causative organism - Staphylococcus aureus
 

Diagnosis - Clinical

 

Management - Systemic antibiotics may be needed for deep infections.

 

Treatment of Acute paronychia -

 

  • Abscesses - Incised and drained (Abscess is often opened by pushing the nail fold away from the nail plate).
     
  • Antibiotics - Semisynthetic penicillin/cephalosporin with excellent anti-staphylococcal orally.

 

Complications - Osteitis and amputation.

 

Lymphangitis: represents acute inflammation elicited by the spread of bacterial infections into lymphatics with group A beta haemolytic streptococci being the most common causative agent.

 

Clinical features: Lymphangitis manifests as red painful subcutaneous streaks & painful enlargement of the draining lymph nodes (lymphadenitis). It is managed by elevating the affected extremity & broad spectrum antibiotics.

 

Chronic paronychia:

 

  • Most common causative organism - Candida albicans.
  • Candidal paronychia is most common in individuals who have their hands in water for a great deal of time.
  • Given recent evidence that Candida colonization may play a secondary role in chronic paronychia, with the primary insult being skin barrier breakdown resulting from wet work and possible contact dermatitis, a role for topical corticosteroids has been demonstrated.
  • Treatment - Topical antifungals & Topical corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metronidazole: Primarily effective against anaerobic bacteria and certain protozoa. While useful in skin and soft tissue infections involving anaerobes, it is not the first-line treatment for paronychia or lymphangitis which typically involve aerobic gram-positive cocci.

 

Option C. Amikacin: A powerful aminoglycoside antibiotic used primarily for severe, hospital-acquired infections with multi-drug resistant bacteria. It is not typically used for initial treatment of common skin infections due to its potential for causing significant side effects, including nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

 

Option D. Norfloxacin: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic used primarily for gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections. While it has broad-spectrum activity, it is generally not the first choice for skin infections and is less effective against gram-positive organisms commonly causing skin infections.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Combination antibiotic Amoxiclav is indicated for the treatment of paronychia complicated by lymphangitis due to its broad-spectrum activity against both Gram-positive and resistant bacteria.

questions.text: A patient presents with a perforation in the tympanic membrane. During the evaluation, a Rinne test is performed. What is the expected outcome of the Rinne test in this case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Negative

 

Perforation of the tympanic membrane results in conductive hearing loss because the sound waves cannot be properly transmitted through the middle ear. In cases of conductive hearing loss, the Rinne test, which compares air conduction (AC) to bone conduction (BC), will be negative. This occurs because bone conduction is perceived as louder than air conduction, indicating a conductive defect. The negative Rinne test is characteristic of any lesion or abnormality affecting the external ear, tympanic membrane, or middle ear, as these structures are responsible for sound conduction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive: A positive Rinne test indicates that air conduction is louder than bone conduction, which is normal or seen in sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive hearing loss like that caused by a tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option C. Indeterminate: This is not a standard result for the Rinne test. The Rinne test is typically either positive or negative, and "indeterminate" does not correctly describe the results related to tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option D. Equivocal: An equivocal Rinne test result suggests equal loudness of air and bone conduction, which is not typically associated with tympanic membrane perforation. This term is not commonly used in describing Rinne test outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A perforation in the tympanic membrane causes conductive hearing loss, which is characterized by a negative Rinne test, where bone conduction is heard louder than air conduction.

questions.text: A neonate presents with post feed vomiting and hypoglycemia in the first week of life. Urine was positive for reducing substances but there was no glucose and urine also gave positive reaction with Benedictâ€™s reagent. The neonate also had reversible oil drop cataract. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Classical Galactosemia


Classical Galactosemia is the correct diagnosis based on the clinical presentation. It is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT), which is crucial in the metabolism of galactose. This enzyme deficiency leads to the accumulation of galactose and its toxic metabolites, causing the symptoms observed in the neonate.

 

  • Symptoms: The neonate presents with post-feed vomiting, hypoglycemia, and cataracts, which are hallmark features of classical galactosemia.
  • Urine findings: The positive reaction with Benedictâ€™s reagent indicates the presence of reducing substances, specifically galactose, in the urine. The absence of glucose further supports the diagnosis.
  • Cataracts: The reversible oil drop cataract is a classic sign of galactosemia, caused by the accumulation of galactitol in the lens of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Essential Fructosuria: Essential fructosuria is a benign condition due to fructokinase deficiency, leading to the presence of fructose in the urine. It does not cause the severe symptoms seen in galactosemia, such as hypoglycemia or cataracts.

 

Option C. Galactokinase Deficiency: Galactokinase deficiency can also lead to the accumulation of galactose, but it typically presents with cataracts alone and does not cause the severe systemic symptoms such as vomiting and hypoglycemia seen in classical galactosemia.

 

Option D. Uridine diphosphate-glucose 4-epimerase deficiency: This is a rare condition that affects the conversion of UDP-galactose to UDP-glucose. Its clinical presentation can vary but does not typically include the combination of severe hypoglycemia, vomiting, and cataracts associated with classical galactosemia.

 

Educational Objective:


Recognize the clinical features and diagnostic findings associated with classical galactosemia, including post-feed vomiting, hypoglycemia, positive reducing substances in urine, positive reaction with Benedictâ€™s reagent, and the development of reversible oil drop cataracts.

questions.text: A psychotic patient developed voluntary purposeless movements and was once observed to be standing still for hours with waxy flexibility and negativism. What is the appropriate medical management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lorazepam

 

The patient's presentation suggests catatonia, which can manifest with features like waxy flexibility, negativism, and purposeless movements.

 

Lorazepam is a first-line treatment for catatonia. It often provides rapid relief of symptoms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Haloperidol is an antipsychotic that can be used in psychotic disorders, but it is not the first-line treatment for catatonia. Additionally, antipsychotics might exacerbate or even induce catatonia.

 

Option C. Clonidine and Option D. Propranolol are not used as primary treatments for catatonia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Catatonia is a neuropsychiatric syndrome that can manifest with features like waxy flexibility, negativism, and purposeless movements. Lorazepam is a first-line treatment for catatonia and can provide rapid symptom relief. ECT is considered to be the treatment of choice.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 59, 67.

questions.text: Most common cancer in India in females is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breast

 

In India, breast cancer is the most common cancer among females. It has surpassed cervical cancer, which previously held the top position. Breast cancer has a high incidence due to various factors, including genetic predisposition, lifestyle changes, and increased awareness leading to higher detection rates. Early detection through screening programs, such as mammography, plays a crucial role in managing and reducing the mortality associated with breast cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervix: Cervical cancer is the second most common cancer among women in India. It is caused primarily by persistent infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) types. Despite its high incidence, it is not as common as breast cancer.

 

Option C. Ovary: Ovarian cancer is less common compared to breast and cervical cancers. It often presents at a later stage due to nonspecific symptoms, making it a significant cause of gynecologic cancer mortality.

 

Option D. Endometrium: Endometrial cancer is also less common than breast and cervical cancers in India. It typically occurs in postmenopausal women and is often associated with hormonal imbalances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among females in India, highlighting the importance of regular screening and early detection to improve outcomes.

questions.text: What hormones are secreted by the Leydig cells and the Sertoli cells respectively? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Testosterone and AMH

 

In the testes, Leydig cells and Sertoli cells have distinct roles and secrete different hormones crucial for male reproductive development and function:

 

  • Leydig cells: These cells are responsible for the production of testosterone. Testosterone plays a pivotal role in the development of male secondary sexual characteristics and is crucial for the growth of the ipsilateral Wolffian duct, which develops into the male internal genitalia. Additionally, testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which is essential for the development of male external genitalia.
  • Sertoli cells: These cells produce Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH), also known as Mullerian Inhibiting Substance (MIS). During male embryonic development, AMH is vital for inhibiting the growth of the Mullerian ducts, which would otherwise develop into female internal genitalia. The suppression of Mullerian duct development by AMH ensures the proper formation of male internal reproductive structures.

 

Note - Inhibin is secreted by Sertoli cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leydig cells secrete testosterone
  • Sertoli cells secrete Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) and Inhibin

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.text: Which of these is the most common site of a branchial cyst? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle

Explanation:

 

The typical location for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle. Branchial cysts are developmental anomalies that arise from the remnants of the second branchial cleft. They are lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, cloudy fluid that often includes cholesterol crystals. This location is key for identifying and diagnosing branchial cysts.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle: This location is typically associated with the external opening of a branchial fistula, not a branchial cyst.

 

Option C. Middle of the sternomastoid muscle: This is not the usual site for branchial cysts. Branchial cysts are more commonly found at the anterior border of the upper and middle third junction.

 

Option D. Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle: This area is not associated with the typical location of branchial cysts. The cysts are more commonly found anterior to the sternomastoid muscle.

 

Additional Information on Branchial Cysts:

  • Origin: Congenital or acquired remnants of the second branchial cleft.
  • Lining: Squamous epithelium.
  • Contents: Thick, cloudy fluid with cholesterol crystals, sometimes clear fluid making the cyst soft and shiny.
  • Branchial Fistula: The external opening of a branchial fistula is at the junction of the middle and lower third of the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle.

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by? (NICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exosome

 

Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by Exosome.

 

Exosomes are extracellular vesicles generated by all cells and they carry nucleic acids, proteins, lipids, and metabolites. They are mediators of near and long-distance intercellular communication in health and disease and affect various aspects of cell biology. These vesicles are enclosed by a lipid bilayer. They are heterogeneous in size (30-2000 m diameter).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosome: Lysosomes are organelles involved in degrading and recycling cellular waste, cellular signaling, and energy metabolism. They do not play a direct role in intercellular communication.

 

Option B. Peroxisome: Peroxisomes are involved in lipid metabolism and the detoxification of harmful substances. They are not involved in intercellular communication.

 

Option D. Genome: The genome refers to the complete set of genetic material within an organism. It is not a structure involved in intercellular communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exosomes are key players in intercellular communication in eukaryotes, mediating the transfer of various biomolecules between cells and influencing diverse biological processes.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

The provided CT scan image shows significant periosteal thickening and sclerosis within the diaphysis of the bone, accompanied by central lucency. These radiological features are characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis. Chronic osteomyelitis is a long-standing infection of the bone, leading to extensive periosteal reaction, sclerosis, and central areas of bone destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing sarcoma: Typically presents with a large soft tissue mass and periosteal reaction. The symmetrical soft tissue in the image makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Usually arises in the metaphysis, with characteristic sunburst periosteal reaction and periosteal lifting, not observed in this diaphyseal lesion.

 

Option D. Fracture: Would present with a distinct fracture line, which is not visible in the image provided. The periosteal reaction and sclerosis are also not typical for a simple fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by periosteal thickening, sclerosis, and central lucency within the bone, which are key diagnostic features visible on imaging.

questions.text: Thyroid hormones play a crucial role in metabolism, growth, and development. They exert their effects through specific receptor types in target cells. Through which type of receptor does thyroid hormone primarily act?  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nuclear receptors

 

Thyroid hormones act via nuclear receptors. These receptors, when bound by thyroid hormones, regulate the transcription of specific genes, influencing various physiological processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytoplasmic receptors: Incorrect. While some steroid hormones act via cytoplasmic receptors, thyroid hormones primarily function through receptors located in the nucleus.

 

Option B. Tyrosine kinase receptors: Incorrect. Tyrosine kinase receptors are typically associated with growth factors and cytokines, not thyroid hormones. Thyroid hormones do not activate tyrosine kinase pathways directly.

 

Option D. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR): Incorrect. GPCRs are a large family of cell surface receptors that respond to a variety of external signals, but thyroid hormones do not act through these receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid hormones primarily exert their effects through nuclear receptors, influencing gene transcription and various physiological processes.

choices.text: Parathyroid gland and hyperparathyroidism
Bone and Metabolic Bone Disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with proximal weakness, lethargy, low/depressed mood, and recurrent renal stones. Laboratory testing revealed a normal S. Calcium and increased PTH levels. What is the organ involved and the pathology? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid gland and hyperparathyroidism

 

The clinical presentation of proximal weakness, lethargy, low mood, and recurrent renal stones, combined with laboratory findings of normal serum calcium and increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, is indicative of primary hyperparathyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism is typically associated with hypercalcemia, but there is a variant known as normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism. In this condition, patients exhibit elevated PTH levels while maintaining normal serum calcium levels.

 

Key Features:

 

  • Proximal Weakness and Lethargy: Common symptoms of hyperparathyroidism due to muscle weakness and fatigue.
  • Low/Depressed Mood: Psychiatric manifestations are frequently seen in hyperparathyroidism.
  • Recurrent Renal Stones: Hyperparathyroidism leads to increased calcium excretion, resulting in kidney stones.
  • Normal Serum Calcium and Increased PTH: In normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism, PTH levels are elevated, but serum calcium levels remain within the normal range.

 

This condition is a diagnosis of exclusion, meaning other causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism (e.g., vitamin D deficiency, chronic kidney disease) must be ruled out first. Given the absence of clinical findings suggesting vitamin deficiency, osteomalacia, or chronic kidney disease in this case, normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroid and Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism does not present with the combination of symptoms and laboratory findings described.

 

Option C. Adrenal and Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytoma typically presents with episodic hypertension, headaches, and palpitations, not the symptoms and lab findings described.

 

Option D. Bone and Metabolic Bone Disease: While metabolic bone diseases can cause weakness and other symptoms, they do not typically present with elevated PTH and normal calcium as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism presents with normal serum calcium and elevated PTH levels and is associated with symptoms like proximal weakness, lethargy, low mood, and recurrent renal stones. It is a diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out other causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with palpable purpura, arthritis, and abdominal pain. A diagnosis of IgA vasculitis was made. What is the indication for starting steroids in Henoch Schonlein Purpura?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G.I symptoms

 

IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-SchÃ¶nlein purpura (HSP), is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes. The classic tetrad of symptoms includes palpable purpura (typically on the lower limbs), arthritis, abdominal pain, and hematuria. While the condition is generally self-limiting and resolves within 4-6 weeks, the presence of gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms such as severe abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, or intussusception warrants the use of steroids. Steroids help reduce inflammation and alleviate the associated GI symptoms, providing significant relief to the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palpable purpura: Palpable purpura is a common manifestation of HSP, but it does not necessitate steroid treatment. The rash usually resolves on its own without the need for steroids.

 

Option B. Arthritis: While arthritis can cause discomfort and joint pain in HSP, it is typically managed with supportive care and does not require steroids. The arthritis associated with HSP is usually transient and self-limiting.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because GI symptoms are a clear indication for the use of steroids in HSP to reduce severe pain and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In IgA vasculitis (Henoch-SchÃ¶nlein purpura), steroids are indicated for the management of gastrointestinal symptoms such as severe abdominal pain or bleeding.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a known allergy to penicillin presents with a enterococcal endocarditis. The physician needs to prescribe an antibiotic but wants to ensure it is safe for a patient with a penicillin allergy. The patient has had previous allergic reactions to penicillin, including rash and swelling. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in a patient allergic to penicillin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

  • The clinical scenario involves a 45-year-old patient with enterococcal endocarditis and a known allergy to penicillin, presenting with previous allergic reactions including rash and swelling. 
  • The physician needs to choose an antibiotic that is safe for a patient with a penicillin allergy as well as effective for enterococcal endocarditis. Let's review the options:
  • Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is not related to penicillin. 
  • It is safe for patients with penicillin allergies and is commonly used to treat gram-positive infections, including those caused by enterococci.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aztreonam: Aztreonam is a monobactam antibiotic that is generally considered safe for patients with penicillin allergies because it does not share the beta-lactam ring structure of penicillins, which is typically responsible for allergic reactions. However, aztreonam is effective only against gram negative bacteria and is not suitable for enterococcal infections which is a gram positive bacteria.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin. Although cephalosporins have a beta-lactam ring similar to penicillins, the rate of cross-reactivity is relatively low, especially with third-generation cephalosporins. However, caution is advised in patients with a history of severe penicillin allergy.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: Piperacillin is a penicillin derivative and should be avoided in patients with penicillin allergies due to the high risk of cross-reactivity and potential for severe allergic reactions.

 

Conclusion

 

The safest options for a patient with a penicillin allergy are:

 

Aztreonam (Option a)

 

Vancomycin (Option b)

 

Given the specific need to avoid penicillin and its derivatives and to treat gram positive (enterococcal) infections, Vancomycin is a safe and effective choice for treating enterococcal endocarditis in this patient. Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

b. Vancomycin
